fr:title.text: Duality theorems for coherent algebraic sheaves › {Ext} of sheaves of modules

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Duality theorems for coherent algebraic sheaves › \operatorname {Ext} of sheaves of modules

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
For every \mathcal {O}-module \mathscr {A}, there exists a cohomological spectral functor on \mathcal {C}^\mathcal {O} that abuts to the graded functor (\operatorname {Ext}_\mathcal {O}^\bullet (X;\mathscr {A},\mathscr {B})), and whose initial page is
746fga1-equation-1.4fga1-equation-1.4.xmlEquation1.4fga1-proposition-1 E_2^{p,q}(\mathscr {A},\mathscr {B}) = \operatorname {H}^p(X,\mathscr {E}\kern -1.5pt\mathit {xt}_\mathcal {O}^q(\mathscr {A},\mathscr {B})). \tag{1.4}
From this, we obtain "boundary homomorphisms", as well as a short exact sequence, which we will not write.

If \mathscr {A} is isomorphic, in a neighbourhood of x, to the cokernel of some homomorphism \mathcal {O}^m\to \mathcal {O}^n, then is an isomorphism for all p. This is the case, in particular, if \mathscr {A} is a coherent \mathcal {O}-module [Ser1955].

Let \mathscr {L}_\bullet =(\mathscr {L}_i) be a left resolution of the \mathcal {O}-module \mathscr {A} by \mathcal {O}-modules that are all locally isomorphic to some \mathcal {O}^n. Then \mathscr {E}\kern -1.5pt\mathit {xt}_\mathcal {O}(\mathscr {A},\mathscr {B}) can be identified with \operatorname {H}^\bullet (\mathscr {H}\kern -2.5pt\mathit {om}_\mathcal {O}(\mathscr {L}_\bullet ,\mathscr {B})), and \operatorname {Ext}_\mathcal {O}(X;\mathscr {A},\mathscr {B}) can be identified with the hypercohomology of X with respect to the complex \mathscr {H}\kern -2.5pt\mathit {om}_\mathcal {O}(\mathscr {L}_\bullet ,\mathscr {B}).

The proof is standard: we consider the bicomplex \mathscr {H}\kern -2.5pt\mathit {om}_\mathcal {O}(\mathscr {L}_\bullet ,C(\mathscr {B})), where C(\mathscr {B}) is an injective resolution of \mathscr {B}, as well as the natural homomorphisms into this bicomplex from \mathscr {H}\kern -2.5pt\mathit {om}_\mathcal {O}(\mathscr {L}_\bullet ,\mathscr {B}) and \mathscr {H}\kern -2.5pt\mathit {om}_\mathcal {O}(\mathscr {A},C(\mathscr {B})).

To finish, we note that the two \operatorname {Ext} functors introduced in are not only cohomological functors in \mathscr {B}, but in fact cohomological bifunctors, covariant in \mathscr {B}, and contravariant in \mathscr {A}.

fr:ol.fr:li: For the definitions preceding , it was not necessary for X to be non-singular, since it was not necessary to work with only finite resolutions. But, if X is singular, then we can no long be sure, a priori, that the (\underline {T}_r^s)^p(\mathscr {A}_1,\ldots ;\mathscr {B}_1,\ldots ) are coherent sheaves, since, in the complex of sheaves \mathscr {H}\kern -2.5pt\mathit {om}_{\mathcal {O}_X}(\underline {L}(\mathscr {A}_1)\otimes \ldots ,\underline {L}(\mathscr {B}_1)\otimes \ldots ) there will be an infinite number of components of any given total degree.

We see, in , that the functors \underline {T}_r^{s\bullet } and T_r^{s\bullet } have, in general, components in positive and negative degrees. Using the above remark, we see that, if the dimension of X is n, then the non-zero components of \underline {T}_r^{s\bullet } are concentrated between degrees -(s-1)n and rn if s>0, and between degrees 0 and rn if s=0; the non-zero components of T_r^{s\bullet } are concentrated between degrees -(s-1)n and (r+1)n if s>0, and between degrees 0 and (r+1)n if s=0 (and, unless I am mistaken, if r>0, between degrees -(s-1)n and rn, resp. 0 and rn).
